moves.1. e4: The game that decided the challenger of the World Chess Champion 2015 Magnus Carlsen.
moves.1... c5: Karjakin opens with e4,Caruana replies with Sicilian defense.
moves.2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4: Black achieves two central pawns against a single one of white,but white has more way to development
moves.5... d6: opens the way to light square bishop
moves.6. Bg5: Karjakin chooses the Richter-Rauzer Attack,a strong line
moves.6... e6: if white capture the knight in f6,black don't need to weaken pawns structure,by re-capturing by Queen
moves.7... a6: defends the b5 square,attacked by two knights and light square bishop
moves.8. O-O-O: white,castling,controls very well the d column
moves.9... h6: most played b5,but Caruana attacks the bishop to make white losing a tempo
moves.10. Bh4: recedes,it's not advantageous here the change
moves.10... b5 11. Bxf6: Now the change is suitable,and black castling is not very safe
moves.11... gxf6: Caruana captures not by queen,to prevent 12.e5 dxe5 13.Ndb5 that threat mate by queen in d7
moves.12. f5: press again to open the centre
moves.12... Qb6 13. fxe6 fxe6 14. Nxc6: White exchanging the Knights prevents queens exchange,since black King would be strong and more safe without white queen
moves.15... h5: threatens Bh6,that pins the queen on the same diagonal of the King
moves.17... Qc5: black defends b pawn by queen
moves.21... Ke7: black king acts now,defending two pawns
moves.22. Bc4: attacks e6 and open the d column for the rook
moves.22... Be3: bishop occupies the same diagonal of his queen
moves.25. Nf4: closes the way to black bishop
moves.28. Qd3: prepares an attack on d6 and put the queen on the diagonal that includes h7
moves.30. e5: but Karjakin advances anyway with e pawn
moves.33. Rh4: double attack on the rock and on the h pawn
moves.34. Qd3: press again on the d column
moves.34... Bg2:
black defends moving the bishop.
Now it was possible a check in h7 by the queen?Black would reply Rf7,white Qg6 that attacks the h pawn already attacked by the rook in h4,but black could defends it by bishop in f3,also attacking the white rook.
moves.35. Rd4: then white moves his rook in d column,pressing more and more
moves.35... d5: black cannot defend putting the other rock in d8,since white would go in a dangerous check by queen in h7,so blocks the way advancing the pawn
moves.36. Qd2: attacks the bishop and the b pawn at once
moves.36... Re4: black cannot defend the pawn,so think to save the bishop.Here if the white queen captures the bishop,black would capture the rook in d4.Caruana at that time of the game had only 5 minutes time,and could not see next move of white...
moves.37. Rxd5:
37.Rxd5!!!
A sacrifice that leads to win
moves.38. Qxd5:
and d column has been finally conquered by white.
White threat now mate in d7.
If 38...Rd8 39.Qf7# 
If 38... Qe6 39.Qb7+
moves.38... Qc7: Caruana chooses Qc7.It seems good,but next move give no chances to black
moves.39. Qf5: threat a check by queen in h7,followed by capture of the black queen
moves.40... Qe5: Caruana,cornered by time and position,tried a last desperate defense
moves.41. Rd7+: no problem to Karjakin finding this move
